title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Helen Elliot, the fair maid of Whithaugh, was wooed andwon by a Charteris of Empsfield; and from her are the present honourablefamily of that title descended.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The shoes which contributed so greatly to the escape of Gilbert Watson,were presented as a memorial to the family of Elliot, and are stillshown to the curious in such matters, by the present hospitable andworthy proprietor of Whithaugh.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: In fact, the strongman of last evening had advanced, towards morning, with provisions andrefreshment to the dungeon; and his shoes being nailed and formed verymuch like those of Gilbert, they very naturally took the twofoot-prints, the one advancing and the other retreating, for one--andoff they set at full gallop--whilst Gilbert and one of Whithaugh'sploughmen made the best of their way in the opposite direction, andultimately separated within sight of Hawick--the honest ploughmanreturning, not a little satisfied with his dexterity to the broad andfertile acres of Whithaugh; whilst Gilbert Watson ultimately reachedsome friends who lived in the Cowgate of Edinburgh--by which means heescaped.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Accordingly,Johnstone, with three of his men, set out in the track from the back ofthe byre, and made sure work of it till they came to the bottom of theglen--their footsteps were confused, and the party seemed to have madeoff towards Whithaugh.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Seeing how matters were going on without, old Whithaugh, who hadhitherto acted merely upon the defensive, discharged a fowling-piece,which he had ready loaded, at the captain of the band.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Infact, the party had been seen advancing, and their purpose guessed at;and Whithaugh had resolved, by the assistance of two stout sons, an onlydaughter of singular beauty, and nearly half-a-dozen ploughmen, todefend Gilbert Watson and his own premises by force.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Having ascertained that one of his troop--one of the most tried andtrustworthy--in other words, of the most cruel and daring--had paid theforfeit of his own temerity, Johnstone uttered a curse or two inreference to the departed's soul, and swore that he would make oldWhithaugh suffer for this.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Tie the creature with cords to a tree,and let us proceed to Elliot's of Whithaugh.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The rental may besomewhat about L. 600 per annum; and, with the income free andunincumbered, the present proprietor is just as rich as he wishes to be,and can afford to exercise that immemorial bias towards hospitality forwhich the Elliots of Whithaugh are, and have always been, quitecelebrated.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The property of Whithaugh has been in the possession of the ancestors ofthe venerable and kind-hearted present proprietor for at least fourcenturies.
